metadata.title: A Chinese Case of COVID-19 Did Not Show Infectivity During the Incubation Period: Based on an Epidemiological Survey
metadata.author: Jong-Myon Bae
affiliations: PhD Department of Preventive Medicine, Jeju National University College of Medicine, 102 Jejudaehak-ro, Jeju 63423, Korea E-mail: jmbae@jejunu.ac.kr
metadata.journal: Journal of Preventive Medicine and Public Health
metadata.abstract: Controversy remains over whether the novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) virus may have infectivity during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms. The author had the opportunity to examine the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period by conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period. The epidemiological findings support the claim that the COVID-19 virus does not have infectivity during the incubation period.

ethical_compliance: This paper is a perspective so it did not need ethical consideration.
disclosures: The author has no conflicts of interest associated with the material presented in this paper.
funding: FUNDING None ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The author thanks Dr. Sung-Huk Lee, Don Haeng Yang, Mi Ya Kim, and Dae Soon Kim at the Bureau of Health-Welfare-Women and Jeju Center for Infection Control and Prevention for their contributions in this submission of an earlier version of the manuscript. AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS All work was done by JMB. ORCID Jong-Myon Bae https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3080-7852
introduction: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) on January 31, 2020 [1]. With the arrival of Chinese tourists and the domestic travel in conjunction with Chinese New Year's Day and Korean New Year's Day holidays, 24 cases were confirmed in Korea on February 8, 2020. As Jeju Island is a popular tourist destination, the risk of influx of COVID-19 and community spread is higher than any other region in Korea.

Furthermore, there is still controversy over whether the virus is infectious during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms. Chinese authorities reported on January 26 that COVID-19 is infectious during the incubation period [2]. In addition, a news story from January 28 [3] and a research paper published on January 30 [4] reported that a confirmed patient in Germany had contact with an asymptomatic woman from China two days before the onset of symptoms. There seem to be evidences supporting infectivity during incubation.

Ethics Statement: This paper is a perspective so it did not need ethical consideration.
CONFLICT OF INTEREST The author has no conflicts of interest associated with the material presented in this paper.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS: The author thanks Dr. Sung-Huk Lee, Don Haeng Yang, Mi Ya Kim, and Dae Soon Kim at the
Bureau of Health-Welfare-Women and Jeju Center for Infection Control and Prevention for their contributions in this submission of an earlier version of the manuscript.
AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS All work was done by JMB.

participants.context: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) on January 31, 2020 [1]. With the arrival of Chinese tourists and the domestic travel in conjunction with Chinese New Year's Day and Korean New Year's Day holidays, 24 cases were confirmed in Korea on February 8, 2020. As Jeju Island is a popular tourist destination, the risk of influx of COVID-19 and community spread is higher than any other region in Korea

CCTV images installed in the hotel and throughout Jeju Island, the patient’s travel route and persons with whom she came into close contact were confirmed [5]. Based on these, the author identified eleven persons who had talked directly with the patient for longer than 10 seconds and recommended quarantine to them. None of them showed any symptoms of COVID-19 infection through midnight, February 8, when the last contact was released from quarantine

summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) on January 31, 2020 [1].
Abstract Controversy remains over whether the novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) virus may have infectivity during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms.

The author had the opportunity to examine the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period by conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period.
The epidemiological findings support the claim that the COVID-19 virus does not have infectivity during the incubation period.
There is still controversy over whether the virus is infectious during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms.
Chinese authorities reported on January 26 that COVID-19 is infectious during the incubation period [2].

A news story from January 28 [3] and a research paper published on January 30 [4] reported that a confirmed patient in Germany had contact with an asymptomatic woman from China two days before the onset of symptoms.
If COVID-19 does have infectivity during the incubation period, it is a serious concern because it effectively neuters the current communicable disease control system.

The author had the opportunity to observe the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period through conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period.

Due to the confirmed diagnosis in China and the onset of symptoms after returning home, she was not subject to epidemiological investigations based on the guideline of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Korea (KCDC).

On the basis of the German case [3,4], Jeju Provincial Government decided to seek subjects who had had face-to-face conversations with the patient on the 24th and 25th, two days before the day of symptom onset, and to take measures to quarantine up to 14 days of maximal incubation period.
CCTV images installed in the hotel and throughout Jeju Island, the patient’s travel route and persons with whom she came into close contact were confirmed [5].

It was suggested on February 3 that the Chinese woman who had contact with the first German patient had already developed symptoms and had been taking antipyretic analgesics during her stay in Germany [6].
It would be reasonable to conduct an epidemiological investigation one day before the onset of confirmed patients in the 5th edition of the KCDC, which is effective beginning February 7 [9].
These epidemiological findings support the claim that there is no infectivity during the incubation period.

Introduction: The World Health Organization (WHO) declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) on January 31, 2020 [1].
Abstract Controversy remains over whether the novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) virus may have infectivity during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms.

The author had the opportunity to examine the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period by conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period.
Results: The epidemiological findings support the claim that the COVID-19 virus does not have infectivity during the incubation period.
There is still controversy over whether the virus is infectious during the incubation period before the onset of symptoms.
Chinese authorities reported on January 26 that COVID-19 is infectious during the incubation period [2].

A news story from January 28 [3] and a research paper published on January 30 [4] reported that a confirmed patient in Germany had contact with an asymptomatic woman from China two days before the onset of symptoms.
If COVID-19 does have infectivity during the incubation period, it is a serious concern because it effectively neuters the current communicable disease control system.

The author had the opportunity to observe the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period through conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period.

Due to the confirmed diagnosis in China and the onset of symptoms after returning home, she was not subject to epidemiological investigations based on the guideline of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Korea (KCDC).

On the basis of the German case [3,4], Jeju Provincial Government decided to seek subjects who had had face-to-face conversations with the patient on the 24th and 25th, two days before the day of symptom onset, and to take measures to quarantine up to 14 days of maximal incubation period.
CCTV images installed in the hotel and throughout Jeju Island, the patient’s travel route and persons with whom she came into close contact were confirmed [5].
Conclusion: It was suggested on February 3 that the Chinese woman who had contact with the first German patient had already developed symptoms and had been taking antipyretic analgesics during her stay in Germany [6].
It would be reasonable to conduct an epidemiological investigation one day before the onset of confirmed patients in the 5th edition of the KCDC, which is effective beginning February 7 [9].
These epidemiological findings support the claim that there is no infectivity during the incubation period.

key_statements: The author had the opportunity to examine the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period by conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period
The epidemiological findings support the claim that the COVID-19 virus does not have infectivity during the incubation period
As Jeju Island is a popular tourist destination, the risk of influx of COVID-19 and community spread is higher than any other region in Korea
Chinese authorities reported on January 26 that COVID-19 is infectious during the incubation period [2]

The author had the opportunity to observe the infectivity of COVID-19 during the incubation period through conducting an epidemiological survey on a confirmed patient who had visited Jeju Island during the incubation period

In the CCTV video, she walked for a long time and appeared to be a healthy tourist without any disease. These epidemiological findings support the claim that there is no infectivity during the incubation period
